questions.neutral: Heard the streets are tense again?

hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, they are. All this talk got folks on edge.
Just a glitch in the system, maybe, more noise than action.
Speaking of noise, been keeping to myself lately.
My adventures? Just fixing stuff here and there, nothing fancy.
Funny how I find peace in those dark, quiet places.
Less chatter, more data streams.
All this commotion gives me a reason to stay low.
Always something in the tunnels, but that's just between us.
Well, looks tense, but what's new?
Tech hiccups getting people riled up, they always do.
Been visiting some off-the-grid spots, when I can.
Keeps me busy—patching up things the city forgets.
Guess you could call it a hobby—fixing the unfixed.
Ran into some faulty tunnel sensors recently; nothing to worry about though.
Need that time away, to see what the concrete world hides.
You'd be surprised how calming those trips can be.
Heh, streets might be tense, but I'm not bothered.
People forget how systems stutter sometimes.
Me? I crawl through old utility tunnels as a way to relax.
Yup, strange hobby but it disconnects me from all this noise.
I'll admit, things have been strange since Halden's, well, absence.
Last week, found busted surveillance in one tunnel; went unnoticed.
Best to embrace disorder, see what's hidden beneath.
Oddly therapeutic, tracing wires where chaos brews.
Yeah, things have a way of bubbling up when systems falter.
I've been exploring tunnels under all that ruckus—helps me think.
Strange solace in those forgotten corridors, I find.
Since Halden died, it's like the city's heart beats differently.
Had an odd night recently—surveillance failures in my usual tunnel haunt.
Nothing gets past me down there, like a safe haven of sorts.
There's a beauty in those often-overlooked, circuit-filled spaces.
So much truth hidden underground—keeps me grounded.
Oh, Alex, streets are always tense when people connect the dots late.
I've wandered through city veins for years—tunnels ease my mind.
A bit of urban spelunking reveals Stenograd's true heartbeat.
Halden's death? It shifted everything, you know—living, breathing city feels it.
Found broken cameras in places no one cares to check, an adventurer's secret.
Those old paths ground me when the world above shifts too much in my palm.
See, my hobby? It's not just exploration—it's knowing where reality's stitched.
It's funny; everyone's eyes are skyward, yet life's rhythm pulses below.
hobby_answer: Ghosts? Maybe just some old echoes.
Tunnels are still just tunnels, you know?
Breaking news doesn't change much down there.
Quiet as always, except for my footsteps.
Yeah, the world is noisy, but I keep it simple.
Ghosts? Just shadows and dust down there.
Same old places, different day, right?
Halden made things interesting, I guess.
Some systems glitched, made things a bit eerie.
Nothing a stiff drink can't handle, eh?
Ghosts? More like the city's old secrets.
Halden's departure stirred up some strangeness.
I felt it down there—something was different.
Wireless was wonky, like the city's nervous.
It's like the tunnels were whispering back.
Ghosts? Just the city's wild stories.
Halden's exit messed with the tunnels' mood.
Found some cables buzzing; seemed alive.
Could almost hear the city breathe—strange, right?
It was my quiet escape, now everyone's curious.
Ghosts? More like where stories hide.
Halden's end? Shook the whole infrastructure vibe.
I stumbled on those wires—ain't that wild?
The city felt jittery, like holding a secret.
My hideaway's been drawing too many new eyes.
